comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: Summary: This is Secretary of War Henry L. Stimson walking beside Chief of Staff of the Army Major General Leonard Wood at President Taft's New Year's Day reception, January 1, 1913 in Washington D. C. The written caption on the plate here reads: SEC'Y STIMSON & OFFICERS JAN 1, '13 Now that we know it is January 1, 1913, and knowing that Henry L. Stimson was Secretary of War at that time makes it a good deal easier to find what the hoo ha of military dress uniforms and top hats is about. New York Times advanced search brings us to: [ query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9900EEDA123BE633A... ] For these headlines and quotes - "THOUSAND IN CROWD AT TAFT'S RECEPTION; Thirty-eight Nations Represented at Brilliant New Year Gathering at White House." + "WASHINGTON, Jan. 1. -- Long before 11 o'clock this morning, which was the hour announced for the opening of the President's New Year reception, thousands of persons stood in line from the entrance gate of the White House to the west door of the State Department." For comparison photos of Maj-Gen Wood see here: and here: www.wood.army.mil/MGLeonardwood.htm Here is the Citation for his Congressional Medal of Honor: history.amedd.army.mil/moh/woodl.htm www.wood.army.mil/engrmag/Maneuver Support Magazine/PDFs for Summer 2008/Roberts.pdf

comment._content: nudecowboy - What building do you think it is then, with the anchor and cannon?  Department of War building possibly?

comment.author: 38331851@N00
comment._content: I'm pretty sure it's the Old Executive Office Building (then the State, Was, and Navy building), now also known as the Eisenhower Executive Office Building
